page.title: Reference
page.paragraph: This section lists out all the Partials and the variables that are made available to them. The Partials are all written using Freemarker. You can find the reference for Freemarker here .
page.title: Flex Item
page.paragraph: Many Widgets fall into the specific category of being a Flex Item. This kind of Widget describes a Widget that will be composed within a Flex Container. The combination of Flex Items and Flex Containers allows for a high degree of control over positioning of HTML elements within one another.
These are the supported attributes that are applicable to Flex Item Widgets specified in Page Definition files.

cell.paragraph: The alignSelf attribute is translated into the HTML flex-box align-self attribute.

row.cell: AUTO, START, CENTER, END, STRETCH, BASELINE

cell.paragraph: The flexBasis attribute is translated into the HTML flex-box flex-basis attribute.
The height attribute is translated into the HTML height attribute.
The width attribute is translated into the HTML width attribute.
The flexGrow attribute is translated into the flex-grow flexbox attribute.
The flexShrink attribute is translated into the flex-shrink flexbox attribute.
The hiddenScript attribute is used to specify a Plantain Script that returns a boolean that indicates if the element should be hidden or not.
The margin attribute is translated to the margin attribute in the HTML page.
The padding attribute is translated to the padding attribute in the HTML page.

The backgroundFlavour attribute is translated into a class that is applied to the element in the HTML. PRIMARY, for example, is translated into a 'bg-primary' class. It's the responsibility of the web developer to make sure all of these classes are available for use: bg-default, bg-primary, bg-info, bg-warning, bg-danger,bg-success, bg-muted, bg-black and bg-white.

row.cell: DEFAULT, PRIMARY, INFO, WARNING, DANGER, SUCCESS, MUTED, BLACK, WHITE

cell.paragraph: The borderRadius property will be translated to border-radius in the HTML.

page.title: Flex Container
page.paragraph: Many Widgets compose or contain other Widgets and need to control how child Widgets are organised. These Widgets are Flex Containers. Flex Containers are very probably translated into flex containers are per the HTML flexbox standard.
These are the supported attributes that are applicable to Flex Container Widgets specified in Page Definition files.

cell.paragraph: The orientation property, translated as the flex-orientation property as per the flexbox specification, controls the axis in which children are presented.
As per the flexbox specification, the justifyContent property is translated as the justify-content css attribute.

row.cell: START, CENTER, END, SPACE_BETWEEN, SPACE_AROUND, SPACE_EVENLY

cell.paragraph: As per the flexbox specification, the alignItems property is translated as the align-items css attribute.

row.cell: AUTO, START, CENTER, END, STRETCH, BASELINE

cell.paragraph: As per the flexbox specification, the wrap property is translated as the wrap css attribute.
As per the flexbox specification, the alignContent property is translated as the align-content css attribute.

row.cell: AUTO, START, CENTER, END, STRETCH, BASELINE

cell.paragraph: The padding property is translated as the padding property in HTML.

page.title: Textual
page.paragraph: Many Widgets present text and as such have a common set of attributes that affect the styling of the text within. These Widgets are collectively referred to as the Textuals. In addition to having presentation attributes, Textuals also compose specific elements related to text. These are Span, Br and Script. These elements are laid out in flowing order as you would expect text to be laid out in a paragraph. Elements are wrapped when space is constrained.
These are the supported attributes that are applicable to Textual Widgets specified in Page Definition files.

row.cell: The fontFlavour specifies the colouring of the font.
DEFAULT, PRIMARY, INFO, WARNING, DANGER, SUCCESS, MUTED, BLACK, WHITE
The backgroundFlavour specifies the colouring of the background flavour.
DEFAULT, PRIMARY, INFO, WARNING, DANGER, SUCCESS, MUTED, BLACK, WHITE

The font attribute specifies one of a limited set of font faces. These names are translated into font faces that are specified in the class mappings file (class-mappings.properties). The actual names are font-title-primary, font-title-secondary, font-text-primary, font-text-secondary, font-exhibit, font-primary and font-secondary.
TITLE_PRIMARY, TITLE_SECONDARY, TEXT_PRIMARY, TEXT_SECONDARY, EXHIBIT, PRIMARY, SECONDARY
The textAlign property is translated into the text-align property in HTML.
The fontSize property specifies the font size.
The textDecoration translates to the text-decoration css attribute.
OVERLINE, LINE_THROUGH, UNDERLINE, UNSET, INITIAL, INHERIT
The fontStyle translates to the font-style css attribute.
NORMAL, ITALIC, OBLIQUE, UNSET, INHERIT, INITIAL
The fontWeight translates to the font-weight css attribute.
NORMAL, BOLD, LIGHTER, BOLDER, INHERIT, INITIAL, UNSET

page.title: Accordion
page.paragraph: The Accordion Widget presents a collapsed stack of panels where each panel has a header that can be clicked to expand the panel. Typically, there is an animation that expands or collapses the panel and hence the name.

The Accordion can be viewed on the right hand side of the
Style Guide Portfolio
page.
The Widget has, in addition to being a Flex Item, the following attributes.

cell.paragraph: The flush property will specify that the Accordion should appear flush-to-the-page when presented. This typically means that the borders and background colors of the panels are suppressed.
The singleActive property specifies that only one panel should be expanded at a time.

page.title: Accordion Item
page.paragraph: The Accordion Item Widget presents a panel as a part of an Accordion Widget. This element must be the immediate child of an Accordion element.

The Accordion Item can be viewed on the right hand side of the
Style Guide Portfolio
page.
The Widget has, in addition to being a Flex Container, the following attributes.

cell.paragraph: This property specifies that this Accordion Item is active when the page is first presented.
The backgroundFlavour property specifies the background colour of the header of the Accordion Item.

row.cell: DEFAULT, PRIMARY, INFO, WARNING, DANGER, SUCCESS, MUTED, BLACK, WHITE

page.title: Accordion Item Header
page.paragraph: The Accordion Item Header Widget specifies a header as a part of the Accordion Item. It is a mandatory child of an Accordion Item.
The Accordion Item Header Widget has, in addition to being a Textual, the following attributes.

cell.paragraph: This property specifies that this Accordion Item is active when the page is first presented.
The backgroundFlavour property specifies the background colour of the header of the Accordion Item.

row.cell: DEFAULT, PRIMARY, INFO, WARNING, DANGER, SUCCESS, MUTED, BLACK, WHITE

page.title: Back Link
page.paragraph: The Back Link specifies a back-link on the page that will direct the browser to revert to the previous web page.

The Back Link can be viewed at the top left of the
Style Guide Question
page.
The Widget is a Flex Item. There are no additional properties.
page.title: Badge
page.paragraph: The Badge Widget specifies a Textual element intended to display a simple message as a number or a one-word sentence. It is mean't to qualify some other element. Words like 'To do', or 'New' are appropriate.

The Badge Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Alpha
page.
The Badge Widget has, in addition to being a Textual, the following attributes.

cell.paragraph: This property specifies the size.
The flavour property specifies the colouring of the Badge.

row.cell: DEFAULT, PRIMARY, INFO, WARNING, DANGER, SUCCESS, MUTED, BLACK, WHITE

page.title: Br
page.paragraph: The Br Widget introduces a forced line break into a Textual element. This Widget is only valid when composed within a Textual.
There are no additional properties.
page.title: Button
page.paragraph: The Button Widget specifies a button for presentation on a web page as a part of a Form. This element is only valid within a Wizard. It should not be part of any predefined page. Buttons define the (submit) buttons on all pages within a Wizard that direct the user forward in the journey.

The Button Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Delta
page.
The Button Widget is both a Textual and a Flex Item. And has the following additional properties.

cell.paragraph: The type of the Button. There are a number of types, and they are all defined and controlled by the Admin Console. From the perspective of the Materials, the Button Widget needs to be styled, but because it cannot be included in any predefined page, apart from the Style Guides, the actual meaning of the attribute is not required.
Similar to type, the actual meaning of this is not required, by the Materials.
Similar to type, the actual meaning of this is not required, by the Materials.
The size of the button.
Similar to type, the actual meaning of this is not required, by the Materials.
The colouring of the Button Widget.

page.title: Card
page.paragraph: The Card Widget specifies a Card; a common HTML presentational element that appears as a card on the page. It can typically have a header, an image, a body and a footer section.

The Card Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Alpha
page.
The Card Widget has, in addition to being a Flex Item, the following attributes.

cell.paragraph: The flavour property specifies the colouring of the Badge.

row.cell: DEFAULT, PRIMARY, INFO, WARNING, DANGER, SUCCESS, MUTED, BLACK, WHITE

cell.paragraph: The link boolean value indicates if this card behaves as a link or not. If this value is set to true, then the user can click anywhere on the card, and it will ink to another web page. You can see examples of this on the index page.
The view property specifies which internal page to link to if the card is a link.
The url property specifies an external url that this card will link to.
The openNewWindow property will specify if, when clicked, the browser will present the destination view or url in a separate window.

page.title: Card Body
page.paragraph: The Card Body Widget specifies the contents of the Card Body. This section of the Card's content will present below the Card Header or Image (if any), and above the Card Footer.

The Card Body Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Alpha
page.
The Card Body Widget is a Flex Container.
page.title: Card Footer
page.paragraph: The Card Header Widget specifies the contents of the Card Footer.

The Card Footer Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Alpha
page.
The Card Footer Widget is a Flex Container.
page.title: Card Header
page.paragraph: The Card Header Widget specifies the contents of the Card Header.

The Card Header Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Alpha
page.
The Card Header Widget is a Flex Container.
page.title: Carousel
page.paragraph: The Carousel Widget specifies a widget that presents a number of panels. The user can navigate to the next or previous panels using slide indicators. If the last panel is reached, then the user is returned to the first panel when the appropriate slide indicator is selected.

The Card Header Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Landing
page.
The Carousel Widget is a Flex Item, in addition to having the following properties.

cell.paragraph: The autoSlide property indicates if the Carousel should automatically rotate the panels.
The indicators property specifies if there should be a series of buttons in the panel that allows direct selection of the panels.
The controls property specifies if there should be a Select Next or Select Previous set of buttons present on the Carousel.

page.title: Carousel Panel
page.paragraph: The Carousel Panel Widget specifies a panel within a Carousel. This widget is only valid as the immediate child of a Carousel.

The Card Header Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Landing
page.
The Carousel Panel Widget is a Flex Container, in addition to having the following properties.

cell.paragraph: The src property specifies an image in the materials that will be presented as the background for the panel. This property is required.
This property specifies if this panel is active when the Carousel first loads.
The interval property specifies the wait period for the specific panel, if autoSlide is set to true on the parent Carousel.

page.title: Cell
page.paragraph: The Cell Widget specifies a cell within a table. The Cell Widget must be the immediate child of a Row Widget. When a Table Widget is specifies, it will immediately compose Row Widgets. The first Row Widget might contain Column Widgets. All subsequent Rows must contain Cells. The Cell Widgets would then contain the actual content of the table cells.

The Cell Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Alpha
page as a part of a Table.
The Cell Widget is a Flex Container.
page.title: Close Workflow Executed Panel
page.paragraph: The Close Workflow Executed Panel Widget specifies that the panel of the same name should present. When a Workflow is first initiated, the platform will present the Workflow Executed Page. This page should indicate that the Workflow that has just executed, has executed. There must be a button on this page that tells the platform to continue. That is the purpose of this widget.
The Close Workflow Executed Panel Widget is a Flex Item.
page.title: Column
page.paragraph: The Column Widget specifies a column header within a table. The Column Widget must only be the immediate child of the first Row Widget within a Table. A Table does not need to have column headers.

The Column Widget can be viewed on the
Style Guide Alpha
page as a part of a Table.
The Column Widget is a Textual.
page.title: Confirm Workflow Panel
page.paragraph: The Confirm Workflow Panel Widget specifies that the panel of the same name should be presented. This panel presents an Accept and a Cancel button. When a Workflow is first initiated by the user, the Workflow Confirmation Page is presented. That page asks if the user is sure they wish to execute the Workflow. The user then confirms or cancels by selecting the appropriate button. These buttons are presented by this widget.
The Confirm Workflow Panel Widget is a Flex Item.
page.title: Confirmation Panel
page.paragraph: The Confirmation Panel Widget is used in two phase authentication. This panel presents a challenge to the user where he should enter a given number of letters at specific positions in a secret phrase. This widget belongs in a specially named page called the Confirmation Page. This functionality is currently not active.
The Confirmation Panel Widget is a Flex Item and Textual.
